title: 107_hr5243
content: The Act is titled the "Rural Safety and Law Enforcement Improvement Act." It includes a section on Small Community Law Enforcement Improvement Grants, specifically outlining the Small Community Grant Program. Section 1703 of the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to allow the Attorney General to provide grants to local and tribal governments outside metropolitan areas for retaining police officers funded through specific programs. Preference is given to grantees facing financial hardship or severe budget constraints impacting the local budget. The amendment allows the Attorney General to provide grants to local and tribal governments for retaining police officers. Grants are limited to 20% of the original amount and $15,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2002 through 2006, with 10% set aside for tribal governments. SEC. 102. SMALL COMMUNITY TECHNOLOGY GRANT PROGRAM. Section 1701 of the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to include a Law Enforcement Technology Program that allows grants to be used for improving police communications through technological advancements. The Law Enforcement Technology Program aims to enhance crime solving technologies, such as DNA analysis and voice recognition. Recipients must provide matching funds of at least 10% of the grant amount, with a waiver available for extreme hardship. The Department of Justice will administer the grant program to prevent supplanting of federal funds. Federal funds provided under this subsection must supplement, not supplant, local technology funds. $40,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2002 to 2006, with 10% set aside for grants to tribal governments. SEC. 103. RURAL 9-1-1 SERVICE. The purpose of this section is to improve communication infrastructure for law enforcement, fire, and emergency medical services in rural areas and tribal governments. Grants will be provided by the Office of Justice Programs to establish or enhance 9-1-1 services in communities without them. Priority will be given to areas lacking 9-1-1 service. The term "9-1-1 service" refers to designated emergency telephone service. Grants under this section are limited to $250,000. $25,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2002, with 10% set aside for tribal governments. SEC. 201. METHAMPHETAMINE TREATMENT PROGRAMS IN RURAL AREAS. Amend Subpart I of part B of title V of the Public Health Service Act to include a new section 510A for methamphetamine treatment programs in rural areas. The Secretary will make grants for substance abuse prevention and treatment pilot programs in local and tribal governments outside metropolitan areas. Grants will be administered by a designated State agency, and applicants must submit required information to be eligible. Grant recipients must use funds as specified. The grant recipient must establish a methamphetamine abuse prevention and treatment pilot program in rural areas. The program should offer in-patient care, social detoxification, neuro-cognitive skill development services, after-care services, and staff training. The grant recipient must establish a methamphetamine abuse prevention and treatment pilot program in rural areas, offering in-patient care, social detoxification, neuro-cognitive skill development services, after-care services, staff training, and using scientifically-based best practices. Grants range from $19,000 to $100,000, with $2,000,000 authorized for this section and 10% set aside for tribal governments. SEC. 202. METHAMPHETAMINE PREVENTION EDUCATION. Section 519E of the Public Health Service Act is amended to fund programs educating rural communities, especially parents, teachers, and youth workers, on methamphetamine use signs and effects. Programs must prioritize prevention and education, with past community experience. The amendment to the Public Health Service Act funds programs in rural communities to educate on methamphetamine signs and effects. Programs must prioritize prevention, have past community experience, utilize professional prevention staff, operate a prevention program, and conduct a community needs assessment. The amendment to the Public Health Service Act allocates funds for rural community programs to address methamphetamine education and prevention. Programs must prioritize prevention, have community experience, utilize professional staff, conduct a needs assessment, establish goals, demonstrate outcomes yearly, and allocate funds for tribal governments. The amendment allocates funds for rural community programs, with 10 percent designated for tribal governments. Grants range from $19,000 to $100,000 per community. SEC. 203. METHAMPHETAMINE CLEANUP. The Attorney General will provide for the cleanup of methamphetamine laboratories and related hazardous waste in local government and tribal areas outside Standard Metropolitan Statistical Areas. This includes improving response time by providing additional personnel, equipment, and facilities. Authorization of appropriations is also included. Authorization of $20,000,000 for fiscal year 2002 to fund cleanup of methamphetamine labs and hazardous waste in local government and tribal areas. 10 percent of grants awarded under this section will go to tribal governments. SEC. 204. Authorization of $20,000,000 for training State and local prosecutors and law enforcement agents for methamphetamine offenses under the COPS program. $5,000,000 allocated for rural communities and $2,000,000 for DEA reimbursement for training expenses. SEC. 205 expands the Methamphetamine Hot Spots Program to include personnel and equipment for enforcement, prosecution, and environmental cleanup in areas outside Standard Metropolitan Statistical Areas. The Rural Policing Institute, part of the STAR Program, assesses and addresses law enforcement needs in local and tribal governments outside Standard Metropolitan Statistical Areas. Training programs cover various topics like drug enforcement, domestic violence, and computer crimes. The Rural Policing Institute, part of the STAR Program, provides training programs for law enforcement officers in local and tribal governments outside Standard Metropolitan Statistical Areas. $10,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2002, with $5,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2003 to 2006, including a 10% set-aside for tribal governments.
